titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Lesley Blanch Papers
titlestmt.author: by Kristen E. Muenz

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 15, 2019 at 04:00
profiledesc.langusage: The finding aid is written in English.

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Lesley Blanch Papers contain correspondence, photographs, artwork, and printed material by Lesley Blanch or pertaining her life and work. Also included are personal and business papers related to her writings and estate, as well as a small amount of audio and born digital material.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.
Box 17 (audiocassettes): Restricted fragile material. Access copies of digital files may be requested. For further information consult the appropriate curator.
Box 18 (born digital): Restricted fragile material. Access copies of digital files may be requested. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Bookblast LTD., on the James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection Fund, 2016.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into seven series: I. Correspondence, circa 1950s-2009. II. Photographs, 1907-2013. III. Personal Papers, 1960-2008. IV. Business Papers, 1945-2009. V. Printed Material, 1850-2008. VI. Audiocassettes, circa 1944-1998. VII. Electronic Media, circa 2001-2011.

bioghist.head: Lesley Blanch
bioghist.p: Lesley Blanch (1904-2007) was an English writer, historian, artist, and traveller. Her works and journeys focused on Russia and the Middle East. She began her career as an artist, studying painting at the Slade School of Fine Art at University College London. She later became a journalist, serving as the features editor of British Vogue from 1937 to 1944. Her first book, The Wilder Shores of Love , was published in 1954. Over the course of her life, she wrote 12 books, and a posthumous collection of her memoirs was released in 2015. She was married to Robert Alan Wimberley Bicknell from 1930 to 1941, and to French novelist Romain Gary from 1945 to 1962.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Lesley Blanch Papers. James Marshal and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.
This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Lesley Blanch Papers contain correspondence, photographs, artwork, and printed material by Lesley Blanch or pertaining her life and work. Also included are personal and business papers related to her writings and estate, as well as a small amount of audio and born digital material.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Lesley Blanch Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by correspondent. Notable correspondents include Joan Bailey, Romain Gary, and Susan Train. General correspondence is placed at the end of the series.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: For additional correspondence, see photographs, personal papers, and business papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence and related materials such as photographs and drawings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains an autographed card from Lesley Blanch to George Cukor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains a postcard from Martha Blanch.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contain letters from Edna Fleming, Gerald de Gaury, Nancy Mitford, Julian Barnes, Pat Kavanagh, and Gore Vidal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains primarily photographs with some correspondence and other related papers. A small number of items in this series have fire damage. This is due to a fire that destroyed Lesley Blanch's home in France in 1994.

did.unittitle: Photograph and invitation, Duke and Duchess of Windsor
Photographs of Lesley Blanch and Romain Gary
Photographs of Lesley Blanch, various locations
Photographs of Lesley Blanch and Romain Gary, Hollywood

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains objects and papers related to Lesley Blanch's personal affairs, including those of her estate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Annual datebooks for 1977, 1990, 1995-1997, and 1999-2007.

did.unittitle: Christmas cards illustrated by Lesley Blanch

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes the documents for the medal of Officier de l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres (awarded to Blanch in 2004) and the documents appointing Blanch an Ordinary of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire (2001), signed by Queen Elizabeth II.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains material related to Lesley Blanch's career as a writer, including clippings of articles she wrote, reviews of her books, and papers related to The Sabres of Paradise (1960). Also included are documents and other papers related to an unauthorized biography of Lesley Blanch (Boston, Anne. Lesley Blanch: Inner Landscapes, Wilder Shores. London: John Murray, 2014.)

did.unittitle: Photocopy of article by Blanch, The Seven Veils of Islam
Materials related to New College Library donation
CDs with material related to theater design

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Use of originals is restricted. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains articles, notes, and publications collected by Lesley Blanch, with some material from her estate.
A small number of items in this series have fire damage. This is due to a fire that destroyed Lesley Blanch's home in France in 1994.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials within this series maintain the original organization found at time of acquisition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains audiocassettes with contents by or related to Lesley Blanch, including recordings of several memorial broadcasts aired after her death.
